summary.summary: This episode, introduced by Lucy Hockings and featuring BBC Health correspondent Philippa Roxby and Ruth Alexander, presenter of The Food Chain, explores the alarming rise in diet-related illnesses linked to ultra-processed foods. These foods, often containing added sugars, emulsifiers, and flavorings, have been blamed for a surge in heart attacks, strokes, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and even anxiety. The episode highlights the role of advertising in promoting these foods, particularly to children, and emphasizes the importance of mindful consumption and checking food labels for added vitamins, fibre, preservatives, and unhealthy additives. The NOVA classification system, developed by Brazilian scientists, categorizes foods based on their level of processing, and Professor Jean-Claude Moubarak from the University of Montreal explains the devastating impact of ultra-processed foods on public health. To mitigate this issue, the episode suggests alternatives like cooking from scratch, choosing non-ultra-processed bread from bakeries, using stock cubes in soups made with fresh vegetables as a compromise, and incorporating lentils and beans into daily meals. Additionally, freezing can be a great way to preserve food, and making small changes, such as opting for water over carbonated sugary drinks, can make a difference. The episode concludes by emphasizing the urgent need to address the issue of ultra-processed foods, which contribute to rising obesity rates and long-term health consequences, and highlights the importance of collective action to promote healthier food choices and reduce our reliance on these foods.

outlines.title: The Harmful Effects of Ultra-Processed Foods
outlines.description: Host Lucy Hockings from the BBC World Service introduces the topic of ultra-processed foods, such as ready meals, chocolates, biscuits, sausages, sauces, and fizzy drinks, which account for the majority of calories consumed globally, being blamed for a surge in ill health, including heart attacks, strokes, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and even anxiety, with BBC Health correspondent Philippa Roxby and Ruth Alexander, presenter of the BBC programme The Food Chain, joining the conversation to explore the issue and its implications.

outlines.title: Ultra-Processed Foods in Our Kitchens
outlines.description: This episode reveals the widespread presence of ultra-processed foods in our kitchens, including whole meal bread, fish fingers, and home-cooked stews with stock cubes, and highlights the role of advertising in promoting these foods, particularly to children, and the need to be aware of the nutritional value of these foods, as even Philippa cereal and mayonnaise can be ultra-processed, emphasizing the importance of mindful consumption and awareness of the food industry's tactics.

outlines.title: The Impact of Ultra-Processed Foods on Health
outlines.description: This episode discusses the effects of ultra-processed foods on our health, particularly in children in the Western world, and how they can be a major contributor to diet-related illnesses. Scientists have found evidence that ultra-processed foods can be harmful to our health, and the episode explores the reasons behind this. It also touches on the fact that many of us start our day with ultra-processed foods, such as cereal for breakfast, and how these foods can be found in our cupboards. The episode raises concerns about the high levels of sugar, fat, and salt in some ultra-processed foods, like dark chocolate and potato crisps, and how they can affect our health in the long run. It also highlights the importance of checking the ingredients and labels on these foods, which may contain added vitamins and fibre, but also preservatives and other unhealthy additives.

outlines.title: The Impact of Ultra-Processed Foods on Our Health
outlines.description: This episode discusses the concept of ultra-processed foods and their impact on our health, highlighting the NOVA classification system developed by Brazilian scientists in 2010, which categorizes foods based on their level of processing, and featuring an interview with Professor Jean-Claude Moubarak from the University of Montreal, who explains that ultra-processed foods, such as packaged snacks, crisps, bread, and cereals, often contain added sugars, emulsifiers, and flavorings, and may have negative effects on our health, particularly for those with health or dietary issues, and in middle-income countries where sales are rising, but the episode does not provide a clear answer to the question of how much more there is to find out about the impact of ultra-processed foods on our health.

outlines.title: The Impact of Ultra-Processed Foods on Our Health
outlines.description: The conversation concludes by emphasizing the urgent need to address the issue of ultra-processed foods, which contribute to rising obesity rates and long-term health consequences, and how this is a global challenge that requires a collective effort to promote healthier food choices and reduce our reliance on these foods.

outlines.title: Reducing Ultra-Processed Foods in Your Diet
outlines.description: Reducing ultra-processed foods in your diet can be challenging, but making small changes, such as cooking one meal from scratch per week, can be a good starting point, and alternatives like lentils and beans can be a great option, and even simple changes like choosing water over carbonated sugary drinks can make a difference, and opting for non-ultra-processed bread from bakeries can be a healthier choice, and using stock cubes in soups made with fresh vegetables can be a compromise, and resisting temptations like crisps requires willpower, and we appreciate your comments on our episodes, and freezing can be a great way to preserve food, like sliced bread, which can be a convenient option.

takeaways: Ultra-processed foods, such as ready meals and packaged snacks, are linked to a surge in ill health, including heart attacks, strokes, and obesity.
Many common foods, including whole meal bread and home-cooked stews with stock cubes, can be ultra-processed and detrimental to our health.
The food industry's advertising tactics, particularly towards children, contribute to the widespread consumption of ultra-processed foods.
Being mindful of the nutritional value of foods and checking labels for added preservatives and unhealthy additives is crucial for making informed choices.
Reducing ultra-processed foods in your diet can be achieved by making small changes, such as cooking one meal from scratch per week or choosing non-processed alternatives like lentils and beans.
Simple swaps, like opting for water over sugary drinks or choosing non-processed bread, can make a significant difference in promoting healthier eating habits.
Ultra-processed foods can have negative effects on our health, particularly for those with health or dietary issues, and in middle-income countries where sales are rising.

transcripts: Hello, I'm Lucy Hockings.
From the BBC World Service, this is the Global Story.
Ready meals, chocolate, biscuits, sausages, fizzy drinks.
We know that processed food is bad for us.
But recent research shows that in many countries around the world, the majority of calories most of us consume are from products known as ultra-processed foods.
These foods are being blamed for an increase in ill health, including heart attacks, strokes, obesity, type 2 diabetes and even anxiety.
So how harmful are ultra-processed foods for our health and given how common they are is it even possible to avoid them?
With me today is BBC Health correspondent Philippa Roxby and Ruth Alexander, a presenter of the BBC programme The Food Chain.
Good to have you both with us.
Hi.
Thanks.
Hi, Lucy.
Hello.
Ruth, I think we need to start with the basics here.
What exactly are ultra-processed foods?
It's industrially made food that's designed to be delicious.
Often the companies making them have really kind of hacked what it is that we crave in terms of taste and they've put those tastes in as additives.
And often food that's marketed at you.
I mean, you don't often see adverts for potatoes or eggs.
They're not ultra processed, of course, but food that's packaged, displayed prominently, particularly to appeal to children, say, marketed and advertised at you.
Ruth, I'm now just mentally running through a checklist of everything that's in my cupboards, in my fridge and freezer, and I'm a little bit worried about what you're about to tell us.
So I know you've also been going through your cupboards.
What have you found?
I mostly cook from scratch, so I didn't think I would find much, but I found plenty.

Whole meal bread, you know, the sliced package variety that you find in supermarkets nutritionally good for you, but ultra processed fish fingers Which I think of as a sort of quick but healthy You know dinnertime thing and I thought well that can't be ultra processed.
It's just fish and breadcrumbs, isn't it?
It was ultra processed mayonnaise.
I'd had a little bit with my lunch when I was going around my kitchen checking things.
Ultra-processed.
Mustard, ultra-processed.
But the 1 that probably surprised me most of all were stock cubes.
I looked at them and they are ultra processed.
So that means that all those home cooked stews I did, all that cooking from scratch I did actually was kind of undone.
If we start at the beginning of the day then, what about Philippa cereal?
So many kids start the day with a bowl of cereal with some whole milk.
Is that okay?
It can be depending on the type of cereal you choose.
There's a lot of cereals that are sweetened, so lots of sugar is added to them.
And actually you've got some here.
They look a little bit chocolatey.
There's definitely added sugar in there.
But then there's a lot of cereals that have our whole grain and have fiber in them and are good for you.
So this is the slight issue with the definition of ultra processed foods is that you tend to think that everything in your cupboard cannot be eaten.
But actually there are some that do contain the good stuff you need.
It's just sorting the good ones out from the bad ones.
I mean
I think 1 of the things with cereal is that they're marketed as being healthy for you and a really good start to the day, particularly for kids.
And this is where scientists are really concerned, aren't they?
Because they say actually, they're the driving force behind multiple diet-related illnesses can be in something as simple as your breakfast cereal.
Yeah, that's right.
I mean, there's evidence that children's, the majority of children's diets, particularly in the Western world, are made up of ultra-processed foods.
So everything from the bread they eat to the cereals to maybe the drinks they have at breakfast.
And that's a real worry because these kids are growing up and what will this do to their health later on?

I mean, there's lots of research, growing evidence that ultra-processed foods aren't particularly good for us, but scientists are still not sure exactly what it is about those foods that's causing the problem.
Is it the way they're made, the way they're processed, or is it the fact that they just contain lots of sugar and lots of fat as we can see here?

I mean we've got a table in front of us full of ultra processed foods and just looking at them, some you could say they're high in saturated fats, salt, sugar, but there's some pretty innocent looking bread there as well.
I guess these are processed to last longer.
They're probably, they look like sort of long life rolls.
So you want them to stay, stay okay in your cupboard so you can eat them for say several days.
And that's why in the food industry they do process things to preserve them and keep them for longer.
So there's some reasons why processing is a good thing.
There are other reasons why processing might not be such a good thing.

Yeah and I see Ruth that scientists have done a big review, the largest review of some of the evidence to date and they say there are 32 harmful health effects from some of these foods that are out there.
But Looking at the table of food in front of us, even thinking about what's in our cupboards, is there any nutritional value or is there some hope there with some of these foods,
Ruth?
Well, that's the thing.
And as Philippa was saying, it's not known why ultra-processed food might be causing harm.
And it could be that there are some foods that are ultra-processed that are absolutely fine for you.
Like my wholemeal sliced bread, you know, has got sort of lots of goodness in it.
It's got fibre, it's got added vitamins.
It's not necessarily that everything ultra processed will definitely be bad for you.
And also, I mean, there's another category just down from ultra processed, which is processed food, and that's not being criticised.
But when I was looking in my cupboards, the dark chocolate that I would like to say is an occasional treat, actually it's probably quite a frequent treat if I'm honest.
But that wasn't ultra- You
and me both, Ruth, I
have to say.
Yeah, keeps you going, doesn't it?
It gets you through.
But that was processed, not ultra-processed.
Is it good for me in the quantities I eat it?
I'm not so sure.

Also potato crisps, another of my weaknesses, is another good 1 to look at because if they've got added flavour they tend to be ultra processed but the plain salted varieties are not considered ultra processed.
Are they good for me?
Well they're full of saturated fat and have high levels of salt, probably not actually.
So it's not clear cut and as Philippa said it's not clear cut what it is about the ultra processing of food that may be harmful.
Ruth, you and I share these guilty pleasures.
I also love crisps, I have to say, as well as dark chocolate.
So, Philippa, I'm standing in the supermarket aisle.
I'm looking at the back of a product.
What exactly should I look for?
In the ingredients list, you're looking for lots of things with very long, unpronounceable names that you would not find anywhere in your kitchen as ingredients.
And those are probably, they could be emulsifiers and additives and flavorings and colorings.
And they quite often have very long complicated names.
And that's a good indication that it's probably an ultra processed food.
What else?
It might have added sugars and sweeteners or fake sugars.
And it may say that it's sort of low in sugar or low in fat and so make that sort of claim on the packet.
And quite often it will come in a package and not look like the original food, not look like a whole tomato or a whole vegetable.
It will be a sauce that comes in a jar or comes in a tin or comes in a package.
Surely the picture is different depending on which country we're talking about.
And I know in 2010, a group of Brazilian scientists said we should be focusing less on the nutritional content of food and more on the form of processing it undergoes.
And they created this NOVA classification, which categorizes foods based on how processed they are.
And Ruth, I know you've spoken to 1 of the scientists who came up with that system, Professor Jean-Claude Moubarak at the University of Montreal.
Did they give you an idea of just how common new PFS are and how difficult and tricky it is to avoid them?
They did.

I actually asked for some examples of ultra-processed food And after about a minute of different foods being listed, I realized it would have been much simpler to ask what isn't ultra processed actually.
So you know, think of packaged snacks, sweets, biscuits, pastries, cakes, pizzas, cereals.

I mean the list just goes on and on and on and the sales of this type of food, ultra-processed food are actually thought to be increasing around the world, particularly in middle income countries where the sales are rising and then in richer countries they're already pretty high.
I mean
you know yourself if

you go to the shops actually, you've got the fruit and veg aisle and then beyond that there are just many, many shelves with lots of different packaged goods and if you look at the ingredients on the back, It's often a long, long list of ingredients.
So there is a fair amount of ultra-processed food out there.
Philippa, these Brazilian scientists only came up with the term UPF back in 2010.
That wasn't that long ago.
So how much more is there to find out about the impact that UPFs have on our health?
Well, a lot more.
It's really a fairly recent term and there's been an awful lot of research in the last few years into ultra-processed foods and how they affect our health and why that might be.
And actually scientists really haven't come up with an answer to that yet.
And so we really don't know whether it's the processing and these added ingredients that are added into the crisps and the bread and the cereals here.
Is that the problem?
Or is it just that we're going back to too much fat, too much sugar, too many calories in our diet.
Philippa, how much harder is it if you've got a health or dietary issue, which means that you have to have these foods?
I know I have a son who has celiac and a lot of what I go to buy him in the supermarket seems to have a lot of UPFs in it.
And it's because it doesn't necessarily have the ingredients in it to make the food stick together or to last a long time or it has a lot of sugar in it to make it taste good.
There aren't many other options.
Yeah, That's true.
I mean, a lot of people do rely on processed or ultra-processed foods for their dietary needs.
Celiacs, for example, have to avoid foods that have gluten in them.
So if you go to that particular aisle in the supermarket, you're going to find things that are quite processed because they need to avoid that ingredient and replace it with something else.
And then there's things like baby formula milk.
That would count as ultra-processed under this classification system.
And yet it's something that's used worldwide by mums trying to feed their babies.
And it comes from cow's milk, but it's had other things added to make it healthy for babies.
There's also vegan foods, plant-based foods.
They would also count as ultra-processed and yet they're seen as very healthy alternatives to meat.

I spoke to Jean-Claude Mubarak about the issue of, for example, infant formula and gluten-free foods and said, well, you know, like they're ultra-processed under this NOVA classification system but people rely on those for health reasons and he agreed and said actually I he said I view infant formula for example as medicine not as food but medicine.
I'm a working mom and I'm starting to feel a little bit guilty at the moment about UPS and what I'm feeding my family.
It's pretty tricky because 1 of the messages is that we should be cooking from scratch and cooking at home in our own kitchens with food that we know where it's come from.
But this is all really time consuming at the end of a long day.
Yeah, I mean, it's very difficult, as we discussed, to avoid every single ultra-processed food.
It's extremely difficult.
And if you're a busy working parent, for example, with young children, You don't always feel you have the time to cook from scratch.
That means starting off with the vegetables and making the sauce from scratch, perhaps, and all the different elements of a meal.
That can be time consuming.
For some people, it makes them a little bit nervous and a bit anxious.
And it's much easier, let's face it, to reach for something that's ready, ready-made, ready to go in the oven, ready to go in the microwave.
It's quite often cheaper too.
And in these constrained times when we're all thinking about how much money we've got in our pockets, that is an easier option.
Cost must be a big factor
for some people when they're considering what to eat.
I think it is and also people are time poor as well aren't they?
Even just stopping to examine the ingredients on the back of packets in the shop.
You know, that's time that you probably don't have.
When I discovered the stock I was using was ultra-processed, thought, right, I'll start making my own stock.
Have I done that?
No, I haven't.
I haven't got the time.
I think like as Philippa said- You haven't got
the time to go to the butcher and get the chicken carcass and bring it home and get the vegetables and put it in the pot.
I mean, yes, you're right.
Just simple stock is time consuming.
Yeah, that's it.
And, you know, when you can go and buy chicken nuggets in the store for very little money, a big bag, and put it in the freezer and it's there when you need it.
You know, that's what everyone is up against.
So I was in the supermarket recently and it's the first time I've noticed this, that people have been standing in aisles with their phones out and scanning food.
What kind of tech is out there to help us identify what's in the food that we're buying and what UPFs are there?
Yes, you can find these apps which will tell you this is ultra processed and also like how nutritionally, what the nutritional value of the food is.
I used 1 in my kitchen.
I must say they're sort of like once you get going on it, you know, I had to make a conscious decision to okay, close the cupboards, put my phone down, just stop this.
What you do is you scan the barcodes and it has a traffic light system where you're looking at green for nutritionally good, green for not ultra-processed, red if it's ultra-processed.
And it just gets you thinking.
But as I say, there's something really satisfying about scanning a barcode and then finding out is this good or is this bad?
I was on a family holiday recently and we got the kids to do all the scanning of the food which they thought was great fun.
Any excuse to use the phone, I don't think they mind.

As long as they've got the phone in their hands They're happy but it is quite a lot of effort to scan a product like this and Chile has an interesting example What their government is doing about UPF's.
Ruth, tell us what they did to tackle high obesity rates
Yes, a few years ago they brought in a system where they have black labels on packaging, which if it's high in sugar or in fat for example.
We did speak to people in Chile about whether they found those labels useful and they said that they did and they do try to avoid those black labelled products.
And we asked them would you find it useful to have a label that said ultra processed and they said yes,
they would.
If we don't, Philippa, get on top of UPFs, what's going to happen in the long term?

This type of food is so freely available and it's cheap and it's very moreish and of course lots of people say that it slips down very easily and it means that you want more very soon afterwards So potentially you eat more of that type of stuff because it slips down our throats easily.
And if children grow up used to eating that way, that will continue into adulthood.
So it's Certainly a worry, but I think scientists have still got a job to do to find out more evidence about whether it's the processing that's to blame or whether it's the ingredients.

And then also, I suppose we all need to think about, every country around the world needs to think about how we can help people choose more of the right kinds of foods and less of the wrong kinds of foods.
But it's a big challenge.
So any other hot tips, Ruth, about how we can realistically cut down on our UPFs?
Probably the thing to do is to start with a small realistic step as well.
If you're listening to this and thinking, you know what, I would like to reduce the amount of ultra-processed food I'm eating.
Perhaps it's just making 1 meal in the week from scratch.
If you're vegan and you're relying on plant-based meat substitutes, which are often ultra-processed, perhaps think about substituting that with lentils and beans, which can bulk out the dish.
I mean, if you just think about what you're drinking with a meal, go for water rather than a carbonated sugary drink which would be ultra processed.
That might not be so popular with your children though, but I'm just saying you could try to do that.
Interestingly, a colleague tried to give up ultra processed food for a month in January and she failed on day 1.
She went to the pub wanting a non-alcoholic drink and all the drinks there were ultra processed.
But I did say to her, you could have chosen water,
sparkling water.
Yeah.

She didn't comment on that 1.

The omelette is not ultra processed, but I suppose the problem is the bread I'm using, it probably is ultra processed.

But you can put it in your freezer and make it last longer if you have a freezer.
That's true.

Yeah, I think so.

It's going to take every bit of my willpower not to polish them off, but it's been lovely to have you with us.
Thanks so much.
Thank you very much and yeah I'm pleased to have avoided that bug of Chris.
Can we resist, Philippa?
No, definitely not.
Thanks so
much, Philippa.
Thank you.
And Thank you for watching.
If you want more episodes of The Global Story, you can find us wherever you get your podcasts.
Don't forget to subscribe so you never miss an episode.
We'd also love to hear what you think of today's episode, so do leave us your comments in the sections below.
Goodbye.
Thank you so much.
Goodbye.

keywords.definition: Foods that have undergone significant industrial processing, often containing added sugars, refined starches, and artificial ingredients, and are being linked to various health problems.
A chronic condition characterized by high blood sugar levels, often resulting from insulin resistance and impaired insulin secretion, and is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease.
A medical emergency that occurs when the blood flow to the heart is blocked, causing damage to the heart muscle and potentially leading to serious complications or death.
A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to the brain is interrupted or reduced, either due to a blockage or a rupture of blood vessels, leading to brain damage or death.
A medical condition characterized by an excess amount of body fat, which can increase the risk of various health problems, including heart disease, diabetes, and certain types of cancer.
A mental health condition characterized by feelings of worry, nervousness, and fear that are persistent and overwhelming, and can interfere with daily life and relationships.
Foods that are industrially made and contain additives to enhance taste, often marketed and packaged to appeal to consumers, particularly children.
Substances added to food products to enhance flavor, texture, or appearance, often used in ultra-processed foods.
Having a positive impact on health and well-being, often referring to foods that are rich in essential nutrients and low in unhealthy ingredients.
Concentrated cubes of dehydrated ingredients, often used to add flavor to soups and stews, but can be considered ultra-processed due to their industrial production and added preservatives.
Foods that have undergone significant industrial processing, often containing added sugars, saturated fats, and salt, and have been linked to various health problems.
A type of grain that includes the bran, germ, and endosperm, providing more fiber, vitamins, and minerals compared to refined grains.
A type of carbohydrate that is not easily broken down by the body and can help promote digestive health and satiety.
A type of dietary fat that can raise cholesterol levels and increase the risk of heart disease when consumed in excess.
Health problems that are caused or exacerbated by a person's diet, such as obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.
A dietary pattern characterized by high consumption of processed and packaged foods, added sugars, and saturated fats, often associated with negative health outcomes.
A type of bread that has been processed to have a longer shelf life, often containing preservatives and additives to extend its freshness.
The process of treating or handling food to prevent spoilage and extend its shelf life, often using techniques such as canning, freezing, or adding preservatives.
The amount of nutrients, such as vitamins, minerals, and macronutrients, that a food provides, which can contribute to overall health and well-being.
Essential nutrients that are required by the body in small amounts to maintain various bodily functions, such as energy production and immune function.
Substances added to food to improve texture and stability by combining oil and water-based ingredients.
Foods that have undergone significant industrial processing, often containing added sugars, preservatives, and other artificial ingredients.
A system developed by Brazilian scientists to categorize foods based on their level of processing, from unprocessed to ultra-processed.
A term coined by Brazilian scientists in 2010 to describe foods that have undergone extensive industrial processing and are often high in added sugars, salt, and unhealthy fats.
Substances added to food to enhance flavor, texture, or appearance, often including preservatives, colorings, and flavor enhancers.
Substances added to food to enhance or alter its flavor, often including natural or artificial flavor enhancers.
Substances added to food to enhance or alter its color, often including natural or artificial dyes.
Substances added to food to enhance its sweetness, often including natural or artificial sweeteners like sugar, honey, or aspartame.
Foods that have undergone significant industrial processing, often containing added sugars, preservatives, and unhealthy fats, and are typically high in calories and low in essential nutrients.

A system used to categorize foods based on their level of processing, with ultra-processed foods being those that have undergone significant industrial processing and are often high in unhealthy ingredients.
A chronic autoimmune disorder that causes the immune system to react to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, leading to damage in the small intestine and malabsorption of nutrients.
Foods that do not contain gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye, and are often used as alternatives for individuals with celiac disease or gluten intolerance.
Foods that do not contain animal products, such as meat, dairy, eggs, and honey, and are often used as alternatives for individuals who follow a plant-based diet.
Foods that are derived from plants, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes, and are often used as alternatives for individuals who follow a plant-based diet.
A nutritionally complete food designed for infants, often made from cow's milk or other ingredients, and is used as a substitute for breast milk or to supplement breast milk.
A system used to label foods based on their nutritional value, with green indicating healthy options, yellow indicating moderate options, and red indicating unhealthy options.
Food that has undergone significant industrial processing, often containing added sugars, preservatives, and unhealthy fats, and is typically packaged and ready to consume.
Food products made from plant-based ingredients, such as soy, pea protein, or mushrooms, that mimic the taste and texture of meat, often used by vegans and vegetarians.
A beverage that contains added sugars and carbon dioxide gas, which creates the fizz, often associated with negative health effects when consumed excessively.
A beverage that does not contain alcohol, often preferred by those who choose not to consume alcohol or are looking for a healthier alternative.
A method of preserving food by storing it at very low temperatures, typically below 0°C, to slow down bacterial growth and maintain nutritional value.
A type of bread made from whole grains, often coarser and denser than refined bread, with a more robust flavor and texture, considered a healthier option.
A small cube of concentrated flavor, often made from dehydrated meat or vegetable stock, used to add flavor to soups, stews, and other dishes.

And so we really don't know whether it's the processing and these added ingredients that are added into the crisps and the bread and the cereals here. Is that the problem? Or is it just that we're going back to too much fat, too much sugar, too many calories in our diet.
I view infant formula for example as medicine not as food but medicine.
It's extremely difficult, and if you're a busy working parent, for example, with young children, you don't always feel you have the time to cook from scratch.

If we don't get on top of UPFs, what's going to happen in the long term? This type of food is so freely available and it's cheap and it's very moreish and of course lots of people say that it slips down very easily and it means that you want more very soon afterwards.

Probably the thing to do is to start with a small realistic step as well. If you're listening to this and thinking, you know what, I would like to reduce the amount of ultra-processed food I'm eating. Perhaps it's just making 1 meal in the week from scratch.
Freezing is just another process. But actually freezing is a great way of making something last for longer as Ruth was saying, sliced bread.
There can be some compromise in there. Yeah, I think so. Well, that's how I'm living anyway.

transcript.text: Hello, I'm Lucy Hockings.
From the BBC World Service, this is the Global Story.
Ready meals, chocolate, biscuits, sausages, fizzy drinks.
We know that processed food is bad for us.
But recent research shows that in many countries around the world, the majority of calories most of us consume are from products known as ultra-processed foods.
These foods are being blamed for an increase in ill health, including heart attacks, strokes, obesity, type 2 diabetes and even anxiety.
So how harmful are ultra-processed foods for our health and given how common they are is it even possible to avoid them?
With me today is BBC Health correspondent Philippa Roxby and Ruth Alexander, a presenter of the BBC programme The Food Chain.
Good to have you both with us.
Hi.
Thanks.
Hi, Lucy.
Hello.
Ruth, I think we need to start with the basics here.
What exactly are ultra-processed foods?
It's industrially made food that's designed to be delicious.
Often the companies making them have really kind of hacked what it is that we crave in terms of taste and they've put those tastes in as additives.
And often food that's marketed at you.
I mean, you don't often see adverts for potatoes or eggs.
They're not ultra processed, of course, but food that's packaged, displayed prominently, particularly to appeal to children, say, marketed and advertised at you.
Ruth, I'm now just mentally running through a checklist of everything that's in my cupboards, in my fridge and freezer, and I'm a little bit worried about what you're about to tell us.
So I know you've also been going through your cupboards.
What have you found?
I mostly cook from scratch, so I didn't think I would find much, but I found plenty.

Whole meal bread, you know, the sliced package variety that you find in supermarkets nutritionally good for you, but ultra processed fish fingers Which I think of as a sort of quick but healthy You know dinnertime thing and I thought well that can't be ultra processed.
It's just fish and breadcrumbs, isn't it?
It was ultra processed mayonnaise.
I'd had a little bit with my lunch when I was going around my kitchen checking things.
Ultra-processed.
Mustard, ultra-processed.
But the 1 that probably surprised me most of all were stock cubes.
I looked at them and they are ultra processed.
So that means that all those home cooked stews I did, all that cooking from scratch I did actually was kind of undone.
If we start at the beginning of the day then, what about Philippa cereal?
So many kids start the day with a bowl of cereal with some whole milk.
Is that okay?
It can be depending on the type of cereal you choose.
There's a lot of cereals that are sweetened, so lots of sugar is added to them.
And actually you've got some here.
They look a little bit chocolatey.
There's definitely added sugar in there.
But then there's a lot of cereals that have our whole grain and have fiber in them and are good for you.
So this is the slight issue with the definition of ultra processed foods is that you tend to think that everything in your cupboard cannot be eaten.
But actually there are some that do contain the good stuff you need.
It's just sorting the good ones out from the bad ones.
I mean
I think 1 of the things with cereal is that they're marketed as being healthy for you and a really good start to the day, particularly for kids.
And this is where scientists are really concerned, aren't they?
Because they say actually, they're the driving force behind multiple diet-related illnesses can be in something as simple as your breakfast cereal.
Yeah, that's right.
I mean, there's evidence that children's, the majority of children's diets, particularly in the Western world, are made up of ultra-processed foods.
So everything from the bread they eat to the cereals to maybe the drinks they have at breakfast.
And that's a real worry because these kids are growing up and what will this do to their health later on?

I mean, there's lots of research, growing evidence that ultra-processed foods aren't particularly good for us, but scientists are still not sure exactly what it is about those foods that's causing the problem.
Is it the way they're made, the way they're processed, or is it the fact that they just contain lots of sugar and lots of fat as we can see here?

I mean we've got a table in front of us full of ultra processed foods and just looking at them, some you could say they're high in saturated fats, salt, sugar, but there's some pretty innocent looking bread there as well.
I guess these are processed to last longer.
They're probably, they look like sort of long life rolls.
So you want them to stay, stay okay in your cupboard so you can eat them for say several days.
And that's why in the food industry they do process things to preserve them and keep them for longer.
So there's some reasons why processing is a good thing.
There are other reasons why processing might not be such a good thing.

Yeah and I see Ruth that scientists have done a big review, the largest review of some of the evidence to date and they say there are 32 harmful health effects from some of these foods that are out there.
But Looking at the table of food in front of us, even thinking about what's in our cupboards, is there any nutritional value or is there some hope there with some of these foods,
Ruth?
Well, that's the thing.
And as Philippa was saying, it's not known why ultra-processed food might be causing harm.
And it could be that there are some foods that are ultra-processed that are absolutely fine for you.
Like my wholemeal sliced bread, you know, has got sort of lots of goodness in it.
It's got fibre, it's got added vitamins.
It's not necessarily that everything ultra processed will definitely be bad for you.
And also, I mean, there's another category just down from ultra processed, which is processed food, and that's not being criticised.
But when I was looking in my cupboards, the dark chocolate that I would like to say is an occasional treat, actually it's probably quite a frequent treat if I'm honest.
But that wasn't ultra- You
and me both, Ruth, I
have to say.
Yeah, keeps you going, doesn't it?
It gets you through.
But that was processed, not ultra-processed.
Is it good for me in the quantities I eat it?
I'm not so sure.

Also potato crisps, another of my weaknesses, is another good 1 to look at because if they've got added flavour they tend to be ultra processed but the plain salted varieties are not considered ultra processed.
Are they good for me?
Well they're full of saturated fat and have high levels of salt, probably not actually.
So it's not clear cut and as Philippa said it's not clear cut what it is about the ultra processing of food that may be harmful.
Ruth, you and I share these guilty pleasures.
I also love crisps, I have to say, as well as dark chocolate.
So, Philippa, I'm standing in the supermarket aisle.
I'm looking at the back of a product.
What exactly should I look for?
In the ingredients list, you're looking for lots of things with very long, unpronounceable names that you would not find anywhere in your kitchen as ingredients.
And those are probably, they could be emulsifiers and additives and flavorings and colorings.
And they quite often have very long complicated names.
And that's a good indication that it's probably an ultra processed food.
What else?
It might have added sugars and sweeteners or fake sugars.
And it may say that it's sort of low in sugar or low in fat and so make that sort of claim on the packet.
And quite often it will come in a package and not look like the original food, not look like a whole tomato or a whole vegetable.
It will be a sauce that comes in a jar or comes in a tin or comes in a package.
Surely the picture is different depending on which country we're talking about.
And I know in 2010, a group of Brazilian scientists said we should be focusing less on the nutritional content of food and more on the form of processing it undergoes.
And they created this NOVA classification, which categorizes foods based on how processed they are.
And Ruth, I know you've spoken to 1 of the scientists who came up with that system, Professor Jean-Claude Moubarak at the University of Montreal.
Did they give you an idea of just how common new PFS are and how difficult and tricky it is to avoid them?
They did.

I actually asked for some examples of ultra-processed food And after about a minute of different foods being listed, I realized it would have been much simpler to ask what isn't ultra processed actually.
So you know, think of packaged snacks, sweets, biscuits, pastries, cakes, pizzas, cereals.

I mean the list just goes on and on and on and the sales of this type of food, ultra-processed food are actually thought to be increasing around the world, particularly in middle income countries where the sales are rising and then in richer countries they're already pretty high.
I mean
you know yourself if

you go to the shops actually, you've got the fruit and veg aisle and then beyond that there are just many, many shelves with lots of different packaged goods and if you look at the ingredients on the back, It's often a long, long list of ingredients.
So there is a fair amount of ultra-processed food out there.
Philippa, these Brazilian scientists only came up with the term UPF back in 2010.
That wasn't that long ago.
So how much more is there to find out about the impact that UPFs have on our health?
Well, a lot more.
It's really a fairly recent term and there's been an awful lot of research in the last few years into ultra-processed foods and how they affect our health and why that might be.
And actually scientists really haven't come up with an answer to that yet.
And so we really don't know whether it's the processing and these added ingredients that are added into the crisps and the bread and the cereals here.
Is that the problem?
Or is it just that we're going back to too much fat, too much sugar, too many calories in our diet.
Philippa, how much harder is it if you've got a health or dietary issue, which means that you have to have these foods?
I know I have a son who has celiac and a lot of what I go to buy him in the supermarket seems to have a lot of UPFs in it.
And it's because it doesn't necessarily have the ingredients in it to make the food stick together or to last a long time or it has a lot of sugar in it to make it taste good.
There aren't many other options.
Yeah, That's true.
I mean, a lot of people do rely on processed or ultra-processed foods for their dietary needs.
Celiacs, for example, have to avoid foods that have gluten in them.
So if you go to that particular aisle in the supermarket, you're going to find things that are quite processed because they need to avoid that ingredient and replace it with something else.
And then there's things like baby formula milk.
That would count as ultra-processed under this classification system.
And yet it's something that's used worldwide by mums trying to feed their babies.
And it comes from cow's milk, but it's had other things added to make it healthy for babies.
There's also vegan foods, plant-based foods.
They would also count as ultra-processed and yet they're seen as very healthy alternatives to meat.

I spoke to Jean-Claude Mubarak about the issue of, for example, infant formula and gluten-free foods and said, well, you know, like they're ultra-processed under this NOVA classification system but people rely on those for health reasons and he agreed and said actually I he said I view infant formula for example as medicine not as food but medicine.
I'm a working mom and I'm starting to feel a little bit guilty at the moment about UPS and what I'm feeding my family.
It's pretty tricky because 1 of the messages is that we should be cooking from scratch and cooking at home in our own kitchens with food that we know where it's come from.
But this is all really time consuming at the end of a long day.
Yeah, I mean, it's very difficult, as we discussed, to avoid every single ultra-processed food.
It's extremely difficult.
And if you're a busy working parent, for example, with young children, You don't always feel you have the time to cook from scratch.
That means starting off with the vegetables and making the sauce from scratch, perhaps, and all the different elements of a meal.
That can be time consuming.
For some people, it makes them a little bit nervous and a bit anxious.
And it's much easier, let's face it, to reach for something that's ready, ready-made, ready to go in the oven, ready to go in the microwave.
It's quite often cheaper too.
And in these constrained times when we're all thinking about how much money we've got in our pockets, that is an easier option.
Cost must be a big factor
for some people when they're considering what to eat.
I think it is and also people are time poor as well aren't they?
Even just stopping to examine the ingredients on the back of packets in the shop.
You know, that's time that you probably don't have.
When I discovered the stock I was using was ultra-processed, thought, right, I'll start making my own stock.
Have I done that?
No, I haven't.
I haven't got the time.
I think like as Philippa said- You haven't got
the time to go to the butcher and get the chicken carcass and bring it home and get the vegetables and put it in the pot.
I mean, yes, you're right.
Just simple stock is time consuming.
Yeah, that's it.
And, you know, when you can go and buy chicken nuggets in the store for very little money, a big bag, and put it in the freezer and it's there when you need it.
You know, that's what everyone is up against.
So I was in the supermarket recently and it's the first time I've noticed this, that people have been standing in aisles with their phones out and scanning food.
What kind of tech is out there to help us identify what's in the food that we're buying and what UPFs are there?
Yes, you can find these apps which will tell you this is ultra processed and also like how nutritionally, what the nutritional value of the food is.
I used 1 in my kitchen.
I must say they're sort of like once you get going on it, you know, I had to make a conscious decision to okay, close the cupboards, put my phone down, just stop this.
What you do is you scan the barcodes and it has a traffic light system where you're looking at green for nutritionally good, green for not ultra-processed, red if it's ultra-processed.
And it just gets you thinking.
But as I say, there's something really satisfying about scanning a barcode and then finding out is this good or is this bad?
I was on a family holiday recently and we got the kids to do all the scanning of the food which they thought was great fun.
Any excuse to use the phone, I don't think they mind.

As long as they've got the phone in their hands They're happy but it is quite a lot of effort to scan a product like this and Chile has an interesting example What their government is doing about UPF's.
Ruth, tell us what they did to tackle high obesity rates
Yes, a few years ago they brought in a system where they have black labels on packaging, which if it's high in sugar or in fat for example.
We did speak to people in Chile about whether they found those labels useful and they said that they did and they do try to avoid those black labelled products.
And we asked them would you find it useful to have a label that said ultra processed and they said yes,
they would.
If we don't, Philippa, get on top of UPFs, what's going to happen in the long term?

This type of food is so freely available and it's cheap and it's very moreish and of course lots of people say that it slips down very easily and it means that you want more very soon afterwards So potentially you eat more of that type of stuff because it slips down our throats easily.
And if children grow up used to eating that way, that will continue into adulthood.
So it's Certainly a worry, but I think scientists have still got a job to do to find out more evidence about whether it's the processing that's to blame or whether it's the ingredients.

And then also, I suppose we all need to think about, every country around the world needs to think about how we can help people choose more of the right kinds of foods and less of the wrong kinds of foods.
But it's a big challenge.
So any other hot tips, Ruth, about how we can realistically cut down on our UPFs?
Probably the thing to do is to start with a small realistic step as well.
If you're listening to this and thinking, you know what, I would like to reduce the amount of ultra-processed food I'm eating.
Perhaps it's just making 1 meal in the week from scratch.
If you're vegan and you're relying on plant-based meat substitutes, which are often ultra-processed, perhaps think about substituting that with lentils and beans, which can bulk out the dish.
I mean, if you just think about what you're drinking with a meal, go for water rather than a carbonated sugary drink which would be ultra processed.
That might not be so popular with your children though, but I'm just saying you could try to do that.
Interestingly, a colleague tried to give up ultra processed food for a month in January and she failed on day 1.
She went to the pub wanting a non-alcoholic drink and all the drinks there were ultra processed.
But I did say to her, you could have chosen water,
sparkling water.
Yeah.
But she just moved on.
She didn't comment on that 1.
But you know, like a quick meal that I enjoy is an omelette sandwich.
The omelette is not ultra processed, but I suppose the problem is the bread I'm using, it probably is ultra processed.
And if you want to find non ultra processed bread, just processed bread, then you're going to have to go to a bakery and that probably will cost more money and it will go stale quicker.
But you can put it in your freezer and make it last longer if you have a freezer.
That's true.
People tend to think that if you freeze something, it's a bad thing.
Freezing is just another process.
But actually freezing is a great way of making something last for longer as Ruth was saying, sliced bread.
Lots of people in lots of countries are very fond of sliced bread.
And the problem with this classification is you tend to think you can only buy very nice, very expensive, rustic whole grain bread.
And that's the only thing.
And
we know how that expensive that is.
So very difficult for families to make that choice.
And sometimes just buying a sliced brown bread from the supermarket is fine and then you can freeze it and store
it.
And also, I mean, something that I often make when I've got vegetables that are about to go off, I make a soup, just get them all in there and make a soup.
I do put, as we know, an ultra processed stock cube in there, but at least it's a pan full of fresh or just about fresh vegetables otherwise.
So, you know.
There can be some compromise in there.
Yeah, I think so.
Well, that's how I'm living anyway.
Ruth, it would be lovely if you were here with us, but maybe it's best that you're not, because given our weakness for crisps, I've got some on the table in front of me.

Thanks so much.
Thank you very much and yeah I'm pleased to have avoided that bug of Chris.
Can we resist, Philippa?
No, definitely not.
Thanks so
much, Philippa.
Thank you.
And Thank you for watching.
If you want more episodes of The Global Story, you can find us wherever you get your podcasts.

Goodbye.
Thank you so much.
Goodbye.

summary.summary: This episode of TED Talks Daily, hosted by Elise Hu, features law professor Alex Carter discussing negotiation strategies to make negotiations less awkward and achieve optimal outcomes. Carter shares her expertise on the importance of curiosity, asking open questions, and the power of silence in negotiation. She also highlights the benefits of adopting a collaborative approach to negotiation, rather than viewing it as a battle. By focusing on everyday conversations and intentionally steering relationships, individuals can achieve better outcomes and build stronger relationships. Carter's talk provides valuable insights and practical advice on how to improve negotiation skills, making it a valuable resource for anyone looking to enhance their negotiation abilities.

outlines.title: Negotiation Strategies for Optimal Outcomes
outlines.description: In this episode of TED Talks Daily, hosted by Elise Hough, who personally struggles with negotiations, law professor Alex Carter shares her expertise on negotiation strategies in her 2024 talk, and how to make negotiations less awkward, and achieve optimal outcomes after the break, sparking curiosity, supported by Capital 1, a key sponsor of the show, which brings new ideas every day.

outlines.title: Banking with Capital One
outlines.description: This episode of TED Talks Daily, which is sponsored by ADT, a company that knows a lot can happen in a second, discusses the benefits of banking with Capital One, a member of the FDIC, which offers no fees or minimums on checking accounts, and features a spokesperson who enthusiastically promotes these benefits, and also mentions that this podcast is his favorite, and notes that certain conditions and requirements apply to these benefits, and customers can learn more by visiting a specific website, which is quite convenient.

outlines.title: Negotiation Lessons from a Kayak
outlines.description: This episode, brought to you by Northwestern Mutual, the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company headquartered in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, discusses the importance of feeling safe and secure in various aspects of life, from personal relationships to business ventures, and how this sense of security can be achieved with the help of companies like ADT, who provide 24-7 professional monitoring, and Northwestern Mutual, who offer a comprehensive planning approach that can lead to better outcomes, as part of the Ted Talks Daily series, which shares lessons learned from unique experiences, such as a honeymoon kayak trip in Hawaii.

outlines.title: Negotiation in Unlikely Places
outlines.description: The speaker recounts their experience in a two-person kayak, where the larger passenger in the back was supposed to drive using their paddles, but the speaker took over, leading to a series of unexpected events, including flipping over three separate times, setting a record, and ultimately, the guide instructs them to negotiate the kayak to the left to avoid hitting the beach ahead, with the speaker getting back in the kayak, dripping wet, and realizing they had missed something important about negotiation, despite having taught it for years, and that many people have misconceptions about negotiation.

outlines.title: Rethinking Negotiation
outlines.description: This episode discusses the concept of negotiation, often perceived as a battle over money, involving losing, and how this mindset affects our behavior, such as the fact that 54% of us didn't negotiate our last salary, according to research, and how this can be changed by adopting a different perspective on negotiation, as presented in a guide, shifting from a contest of wills to a more collaborative approach, like steering a kayak towards a beach, and shares 5 lessons that can change one's life, drawing an analogy from a personal experience of being dunked in a river just 5 minutes earlier.

outlines.title: Negotiation as Steering
outlines.description: Negotiation as steering involves intentionally focusing on everyday conversations to steer relationships, like steering a kayak to reach our goal, and this concept became apparent after a honeymoon, where opportunities to negotiate were everywhere, including getting to know bosses better and understanding their priorities, as well as regularly calling clients to ask about their businesses, and steering our relationships almost every minute of the day, and when we do get to money conversations, we are more likely to be successful, which brings us to lesson 2.

outlines.title: The Power of Asking Questions in Negotiation
outlines.description: This episode discusses a study by a professor where participants were set up to negotiate, and how curious people can make more money by utilizing a specific negotiation technique that most people are not using, which involves asking open questions first, rather than leading with points, and how this technique can lead to a better outcome, with only 7% of people achieving the optimal outcome, by uncovering the other person's needs and concerns, unlike closed questions that often result in one-word answers, as illustrated by the example of asking for good information about a trip.

outlines.title: Negotiation Strategies
outlines.description: This episode discusses negotiation strategies, focusing on Lesson 3, the power of the first question, such as asking a hiring manager about the salary range or a teenager about their reasons for requesting a $50 weekly allowance, and Lesson 4, landing the plane, and also explores the concept of the mirror, where we have to negotiate with ourselves before negotiating with others, considering our priorities, gathering data on effective strategies, and how research shows that thinking about past successes can lead to better negotiation outcomes.

outlines.title: The Secret to Great Deals
outlines.description: The episode reveals the secret to great deals, involving a sales executive who loses deals due to talking too much, and the importance of silence in negotiation, which can lead to a high-value move, and how to use customer reviews to justify a higher price point compared to competitors, and land the plane by making your adversary your partner, as outlined in lesson 5, all within a 3.5-second window of silence, making the negotiation collaborative and effective in making a proposal, and overcoming nervousness to survive the silence and ask the right question, ultimately turning your adversary into a partner.

outlines.title: Negotiation is Steering
outlines.description: This episode discusses the art of negotiation, highlighting a situation where a diplomat had to negotiate with a counterpart who felt disrespected and was threatening to leave, ultimately leading to a successful peace deal, demonstrating that negotiation is not a battle, but rather a process of steering towards a common goal, often with the person who was initially seen as an adversary becoming a partner in the end, much like in everyday negotiations with a boss or a home contractor, where the key is to recruit the other party as a co-conspirator, driven by curiosity about each other's needs and goals, and leading to long-term relationships, like the speaker's 18-year marriage, which has been a successful negotiation, albeit not always in a kayak, and supported by sponsors like Progressive insurance and the Defender 110.

outlines.title: The New Defender 110
outlines.description: Alex Carter spoke at TEDxReno in 2024 about the new Defender 110, a vehicle made to go further, part of the Defender family, including the two-door Defender 90 and the Defender 130, seating up to 8 people, great for trips and big families, with a thoroughly modern design and robust materials built with integrity, and this episode is part of the TED Talks Daily and the TED Audio Collective, produced and edited by a team including Martha Estefanos, Oliver Friedman, Brian Green, Autumn Thompson, and Alejandra Salazar.

outlines.title: Episode Credits and Closing
outlines.description: Hosted by Elise Hu, this episode was mixed by Christopher Faisy-Bogan, with additional support from Emma Taubner and Daniel Ballezo, and she will be back tomorrow with a fresh idea for your feed, thanks for listening to PRX, a production of PRX, wrapping up this episode.

takeaways: Negotiation is not a battle, but a collaborative process of steering towards a common goal.
Adopting a curious approach to negotiation can lead to better outcomes, as it helps to uncover the other person's needs and concerns.
Asking open questions first, rather than leading with points, can lead to a better outcome in negotiations.
The power of the first question can set the tone for a successful negotiation, so choose it wisely.
Silence can be a powerful tool in negotiation, allowing the other party to reveal their needs and concerns.
Negotiation is not just about money, but about building relationships and understanding the other person's priorities.
Thinking about past successes can lead to better negotiation outcomes, so reflect on your experiences before entering a negotiation.
Recruiting the other party as a co-conspirator, driven by curiosity about each other's needs and goals, can lead to long-term relationships and successful negotiations.

I arrive in Hawaii and I look adoringly at my brand new husband as we get in a two-person kayak together for a river tour.
Then things go wrong.
Fast.
You see, in a two-person kayak, the passenger in the back, usually the larger passenger, is supposed to drive using their paddles.
Well, I didn't like how he was driving.
So I decided to drive my own way.
And exactly at the moment I thought I had taken over, we flipped over 3 separate times.
Apparently we set a record.
So I get back in the kayak, now dripping wet, when our guide up ahead turns back and says, okay, folks, let's negotiate these things to the left because you're gonna hit that beach up ahead.
Negotiate the kayak.
In that moment I realized that although I had been teaching negotiation for a few years already, I had missed something important.
And I was not alone.
A lot of us have misconceptions about negotiation.
We're taught that it's a battle over money, that it involves losing.
So we either fear it or we avoid it altogether.
In fact, 54% of us didn't negotiate our last salary.
That's from research, by the way.
I'm not actually seeing into your souls.
The fact is that Before that guide, I had never heard anyone use the word negotiate that way before.
I too had absorbed this message that it was a contest of wills, you know, like 5 minutes earlier when I dunked us in the river.
But there's another way to think about it, isn't there?
When I negotiate my kayak toward a beach, what am I doing?
I'm steering.
Today, I want to share 5 lessons about negotiation that just might change your life.
And the first is this.
Negotiation is simply steering.
It is any conversation in which you are steering a relationship and it's so much more than the money conversations.
You know, just like a kayak where we want to steer consistently to get to our goal, we can be steering our relationships almost every minute of the day.
You know, when I got back from that honeymoon, I looked around and I saw opportunities to negotiate everywhere.
I could be getting to know my bosses better so that I understood what they prioritized most.
I could be calling my clients regularly and asking them what was new in their businesses.
And I realized something powerful.
If we intentionally focus on the everyday steering, what happens when we do get to the money conversations?
We are more likely to be successful.
Which brings me to lesson 2.
Curious people make more money.
There's 1 negotiation technique that most of us are not using.
So years ago, a professor set people up to negotiate as part of a study.
Only 7% of those people achieved the optimal outcome.
What did they do?
Well, they didn't lead with their points.
They asked questions first.
Bottom line, in negotiation, you get more by asking questions than you do by arguing.
But not just any questions.
That 7%, they asked open questions, questions that uncovered the other person's needs, concerns, and goals.
And most of us aren't great at that.
When I teach people about asking questions, I say, OK, I've just taken a trip.
What can you ask me to get some good information?
Top 2 questions they ask, I bet you could guess.
Number 1, where did you go?
Reno, did you have a Good time?
Yeah.
2 closed questions, 2 one-word answers.
So what's the best question?
Well, It's a little bit of a trick because technically, the best question of all doesn't end with a question mark.
It's tell me all about your vacation.
Tell me is the biggest question you can ask and it is the most powerful first question in any negotiation at work or at home.
With the hiring manager, tell me how the company sees the salary range for this position.
With your teenager, tell me what's making you ask for a $50 a week allowance.
Tell Me gets you the most information, but it also builds trust, so it creates the best deals.
And now back to
the episode.
Lesson 3.
The negotiation starts before the negotiation starts.
Most people don't know that every negotiation actually comes in 2 parts.
The second part we all know about.
That's where we're sitting down with someone else.
But that first part, that's what I call the mirror.
Because we have to negotiate with ourselves first before we negotiate with anyone else.
And it's the most critical part of the negotiation too, because if we don't get this right, the negotiation stops there.
We don't ask.
We get confused about our priorities.
We shut ourselves down before we give anybody else the chance.
If you want to master the mirror, try asking yourself, how have I handled something like this successfully before?
Did you know that research shows if we think about a time and write it down, that we achieved great results before we go in to negotiate, we are more likely to negotiate well.
Why?
Because we remind ourselves of who we are at our most powerful and we also gather data on strategies that are likely to work for us.
Lesson 4, land the plane.
I worked with a brilliant sales executive who sometimes would lose deals because he talked too much.
He'd ask a great question and then he would get scared of the silence so he would eat it up with his words.
What do you need to get this done here today?
Well, I know our price point might be a little bit higher than that of our competitors, but I think if you go ahead and look at our customer reviews...
Want to know the secret to great deals?
Shut up.
Recent research found that leaving a period of silence in negotiation not only made it more likely that the other person would give you a high-value move, but it also came across as collaborative.
So how much silence?
I just did it.
3 and a half seconds.
See, you were nervous, but we all survived.
That's what I call landing the plane.
Ask your question, make your proposal, and then zip it.
And finally, lesson 5, make your adversary your partner.
It's 3 a.m.
And you have 5 hours to go before the entire world is expecting you and several other countries to announce a peace deal.
But right now, you have a problem because 1 of the other country's diplomats has left the building and is down in the parking lot threatening to drive away because he feels disrespected.
This was the situation that 1 of the diplomats I worked with faced.
But a lot of us face things like this in our everyday negotiations.
So much of the popular wisdom talks about our adversary, our opponent.
Well, in most everyday negotiations, that adversary at the bargaining table becomes our partner once that deal is done.
The boss who holds the keys to your raise, once you get it, you're working together.
Or that home contractor you're negotiating with over your kitchen.
Once you settle on a price, you're trusting her to build a room you're gonna love for years to come.
And even when your spouse might feel like an opponent, well, you're still sleeping in the same bed at the end of the day.
That diplomat I worked with, He walked out of the building, down to the parking lot, and he approached the man who had left.
He said to him, we are on the same side.
He listened.
Eventually, the 2 men walked together back into that building and later they announced that peace deal.
My negotiation motto is this, I never request, I recruit.
I don't want to talk to someone across the table.
I want to pull them around with questions to my side of the table so that we are now co-conspirators working toward the same goal.

It is simply steering.

Thank you.

summary.summary: This episode discusses the story of Chip Wilson, a visionary entrepreneur who leveraged his experience working on the Alaska oil pipeline and his passion for sports to build a business empire. Born into a middle-class family in Calgary, Canada, Wilson was driven by his goals to own his own house by 20, be in his own business by 30, and retire by 40. He achieved these goals through his entrepreneurial ventures, including founding West Beach, a snowboarding apparel brand in Calgary, and later, Lululemon, a yoga-inspired athletic apparel brand that revolutionized the industry. Wilson's journey was marked by his ability to seize opportunities, overcome challenges, and adapt to changing market trends. He successfully navigated the transition from a small startup to a global brand, and his leadership was instrumental in shaping the company's culture and values. Today, Wilson serves as the executive director of Hold It All, Incorporated, and continues to pursue his passions, including coaching flag football for his 12-year-old twin boys. Through his story, we gain insights into the power of entrepreneurship, innovation, and perseverance.

outlines.title: How Chip Wilson Built Lululemon
outlines.description: This episode of How I Built This from NPR discusses the story of Chip Wilson, a very attentive entrepreneur who noticed a trend in yoga in Vancouver in the late 1990s and just seized the opportunity, which is a classic case of seeing a chance and taking it, resulting in a super interesting story about how he built Lululemon, a breakout brand worth billions, and it all started with a trend that seemed to be everywhere, particularly among women, and this entrepreneur was definitely the kind of person who was very attentive to trends and saw the potential in turning workout clothes into a fashion statement, which became known as leisure, and people started wearing gym clothes outside of the gym on purpose, as discussed by Guy Raz in this episode, which first ran in June 2018.

outlines.title: Chip's Journey
outlines.description: Chip, from a middle-class family in Calgary, Canada, had a rather interesting life, with various experiences that have shaped him into the person he is today, including playing hockey and football, learning how to sew from his mother, who was a seamstress, and having a father who was a phys-ed teacher, and working for an oil company on the Alaska oil pipeline, and later applying the skills he learned from his mother, such as working with fabric patterns, to his career in big production, which was a valuable asset in saving thousands of dollars.

outlines.title: The Birth of West Beach and the Rise of Baggy Shorts
outlines.description: The guest's experience working on the Alaska oil pipeline led to a significant amount of money, approximately $600,000 in today's dollars. At just 19 years old, the guest was given a substantial amount of cash, which they used to pursue their passions. The guest had three goals in mind: to own their own house by 20, be in their own business by 30, and retire by 40. The guest's experience in Calgary played a crucial role in shaping their future endeavors, including their foray into fashion, where they created loud flowered prints and reversible shorts that became popular among skateboarders. The guest pioneered vertical retailing by setting up a lemonade stand-like operation, selling their shorts for $1,000 a day. The guest's brand, West Beach, was inspired by their love of the beach lifestyle, which they experienced growing up in San Diego. The guest's story is a testament to the power of taking risks and pursuing one's passions.

outlines.title: Building a Snowboarding Apparel Brand
outlines.description: This episode discusses the journey of building a snowboarding apparel brand, starting from the founder's passion for the sport and his vision to create a unique brand identity, which eventually led to the establishment of West Beach in Calgary, a city that played a crucial role in the brand's early success, and later expanding to Toronto, and participating in trade shows in Singapore and Munich to gain international recognition, focusing on producing high-quality snowboarding clothing to achieve economy of scale and stay competitive, with Japan emerging as a significant market, before eventually selling the brand to Morill Snowboards, and the founder moving to Vancouver, where he reflected on his journey and the pursuit of financial independence.

outlines.title: How I Built This: Lululemon
outlines.description: This episode discusses the story of how Chip Wilson built Lululemon, a company that revolutionized the athletic clothing industry. Wilson, who had previously founded Westbeach Snowboard, attended a yoga class in Vancouver and noticed the lack of comfortable and functional clothing for women. He saw an opportunity to create a new type of athletic clothing that would cater to the growing demand for yoga and running gear. With his experience in the snowboarding industry, Wilson was able to bring a unique perspective to the world of athletic clothing. He consulted with Fiona Stang, his yoga instructor, and traveled to Japan to purchase four flat seam machines for $40,000 each, allowing him to create a new type of fabric that would be comfortable, functional, and fashionable, using lycra stretch pants as inspiration, and incorporating moisture-wicking fabric and anti-stink technology, targeting the demographic of university graduates, 60% of whom were women in 1998, and focusing on seamless construction to eliminate chafing.

outlines.title: The Founding of Lululemon
outlines.description: This episode discusses the founding of Lululemon, a popular athletic apparel brand, by Chip Wilson in Vancouver, and how it became a huge success, thanks to its focus on yoga and technical features, and how word of mouth helped spread the brand, and how Shannon Gray became the CEO, and how Chip Wilson left to run West Beach, and how Lululemon expanded to Toronto, Santa Monica, and Melbourne, and how it became a global brand, and how it used a naked promotion to attract customers, and how the police were surprisingly cool about it, and how it caused a traffic jam, and how it's all very impressive.

outlines.title: Scaling a Business and Managing Growth
outlines.description: This episode discusses the challenges of scaling a business, particularly when it comes to managing cash flow and expanding manufacturing and retail stores, and how these issues can impact growth and profitability, and the decision to seek outside investors in 2005, which led to a change in leadership, with the founder stepping down as CEO, and the success of global manufacturing efforts, which allowed the company to triple its profit, and the personal concerns of the founder, including his wife's fears about the business, and the risk of unexpected events, such as an earthquake, and the founder's decision to sell half of the company, relinquishing 100% ownership, and the role of this decision in facilitating growth and expansion.

outlines.title: Chip Wilson's Lululemon Journey
outlines.description: Lululemon founder Chip Wilson reflects on the challenges he faced, including quality issues that led to a recall, and how he navigated the media scrutiny, including a Bloomberg interview, where he discussed the issue of pilling, which occurs when friction causes the fabric to break down, and how it was misinterpreted as a comment on women's bodies.

outlines.title: Chip Wilson on Lululemon and Entrepreneurship
outlines.description: Chip Wilson, founder of Lululemon, discusses his experiences as an entrepreneur, including his time at Lou Lemon, and how it relates to his current life and business ventures, such as being a liability after 30 years of doing thousands of public interviews, and how he had envisioned Lululemon reaching $7-8 billion in sales, but left when it was at $2 billion, and is now the executive director of Hold It All, Incorporated, a position he has held since leaving Lululemon in 2015, and also enjoys coaching flag football for his 12-year-old twin boys, which is a topic that is explored in depth, with many interesting insights and anecdotes about his journey.

takeaways: Chip Wilson, founder of Lululemon, built a successful brand by seizing opportunities and taking calculated risks.
Attentiveness to trends and consumer needs is crucial for entrepreneurial success.
Wilson's diverse experiences, including working on the Alaska oil pipeline and learning to sew, contributed to his unique perspective and skills.
Setting clear goals and pursuing passions can lead to achieving financial independence and success.
Pioneering vertical retailing and focusing on high-quality products helped Wilson's brands gain international recognition.
Lululemon revolutionized the athletic clothing industry by creating comfortable, functional, and fashionable clothing for women.
Scaling a business requires careful management of cash flow, manufacturing, and retail expansion to maintain growth and profitability.
Seeking outside investors can facilitate growth but may require relinquishing control and adapting to new leadership.
Entrepreneurs must navigate challenges, including quality issues and media scrutiny, while maintaining their vision and integrity.
