That's how I was able to make
more cash, exactly.
And so we should foreshadow, there's a foreshadowing here that Shannon eventually becomes your wife.
You're now married to Shannon, she's your wife.
So Lululemon really launches in 98 in this neighborhood in Vancouver and does it take off right away?
Is it just like insane or was it a slow burn?
It was very slow burn and then it was so slow that even when I left for to run West Beach, we were running out of money.
I had a lot of inventory because I needed to make at least 5 to 600 of every of our 6 styles in order to get the price down.
So I fell into the trap of wholesaling.
And so I made a big deal to wholesale to a sporting goods company in Vancouver and I shipped to them and they immediately went bankrupt.
So that really took the company to the very edge.
We had no money to pay payroll again.
I was only a couple weeks away from the end of it.
We had just decided to move across the street from our second floor into a store on the main floor on 4th Avenue at $10 a square foot because it was an old, beat-up electronics store.
And then another thing from heaven came and it was, they fired me at West Beach.
Well, and I use that loosely, but they combined with Sim Skateboards and the CEO of Sim Skateboards became the CEO.
So they let me go with a severance fee of $50, 000.
And if it wasn't for that $50, 000, we never would have been able to finish our store.
Wow.
Just before Christmas time.
This is in 2000?
Yeah, this is in 2000.
And Even though we had this great yoga pant and tops, Shannon had designed this polar fleece bra, which got into the newspaper and brought everybody into the store.

And of course, while they were there, they mostly bought the yoga pants because we were in a position then to educate people on the technical features of our pant, and once we had somebody in them, they were a customer for life.
And if you were taking a yoga class in Vancouver at that time, presumably you would have seen the label, because the label was like right on the outside of the waistband, right?
Yeah, I put it there because I was very clear that I didn't want big logoing, and I thought that somebody should look in the mirror and not see any logos.
And I definitely didn't like logos on the left breast because I looked at it as being kind of corporate logoing, you know, it's always there on the left chest.
So I decided I wanted the logo small, I wanted to be discreet and in a place that nobody could see.
So you, I guess around 2002, you opened your first store outside of Vancouver.
This is in Toronto or Toronto, as they say in Toronto.
Yeah.
So we had, in my second floor, you know, in Vancouver was a really a pop-up store in the, you know, where people had to really look and find it.
We did the same thing in Toronto almost a year before we opened the store there.
We got a way of developing the marketplace which became a leu lemon business model.

We would go into every city in the future, set up a store in a back alley or in a side street and develop our market, invite yoga instructors in before we spent, you know, $600 to a million dollars on a store.
And, you know, again created word of mouth, which was, you know, my favorite type of marketing is breakeven marketing, because I never had any money for marketing, so that was a given.
Well, you did.
I mean, you guys did some, some stunts, right?
Like when you opened your shop in Vancouver, you said the first 30 people who show up naked get a free outfit?
Well, it was worse than that.
I actually put my first ad in as anyone that shows up gets a free outfit.
And then I realized it was in Vancouver, and I was gonna get every person in the whole city would show up naked, so I couldn't really do that.
So I had to put another ad in a week later saying the first 30.
And did that happen?
Oh yeah, and it created global media.
Everybody showed up.
There was TV trucks all up and down the street.
People were just
naked in front of the store?
Well they showed up.
It was October morning.
You probably never heard this about Vancouver, it was overcast and drizzly.

You know, they all showed up in their trench coats and then, you know, we went out, when we went to open the store, I went out with my wife and put my arm around her and then we said thanks for coming and everyone dropped their trench coats and went running into the store.
This is, and like nobody was arrested because like this is not normally allowed in most cities.
Well, especially in 2002, but I think it's part of the culture here and there's lots of nude beaches, so I don't think it was out of the realm for Vancouverites.
I'm very proud of our city and our police for stepping back and just observing.
So around 2002, Lululemon really starts to grow.
Like 2003, you opened your first store in the U.S.
In Santa Monica, which obviously you chose that because that was sort of, right, the center of the yoga culture in the U.S., I guess.
Yeah, I think probably the big thing that happened after we opened up Toronto and the second store in Vancouver is, you know, I asked my lovely wife to marry me.
She said yes.

And so it was April 20th, Saturday when we were to get married and I'm working in the store and really I became almost a traffic cop because the the number of people coming to the store was something they would never seen before.
I think it went from a 10000 dollar Saturday to a 30000 dollar Saturday.
So obviously like you've got a store in Toronto, you've got 1 in Santa Monica, and then I guess your next stop was Melbourne, Australia.
You're growing fast.
But you still, I'm assuming you didn't have enough cash flow to really scale the business at that point.
Well, I only after that we started making a lot of money and I don't just don't mean a little bit of money.
I mean a lot of money.
I
mean you have to understand that again that nobody in the world had was owning manufacturing right to the retail store.
I mean, I was taking triple the profit of most people.

But I mean, I guess It was 2005 that you went out and sought outside investors who then, because at that point you'd owned 100% of the company, so you sold I guess about half of the company and then stepped down as a CEO.
Why did you do that?
Was that the only way you could expand and scale?
No, no.
I mean, because I had built retail stores around the world, I had done global manufacturing, I mean, honest to God, I could have done it all.
But even though it was making so much money, I'd never taken any money out.
My wife and I, neither of us came for money and we were always scared.
You
know, we were scared that an earthquake would hit or you know, like this seems really good but is it true?
Is it happening?
We'd have to pinch ourselves every morning.
And then, and I wanted advisors.
I wanted people around me that could make sure that I wasn't going to run into roadblocks.
Okay, so you've sold about half the company to private investors.
A new CEO comes in.
You stay on as chairman.
And then I guess you become like chief innovation officer at this point, right?
Right.
And it allowed me to sit in the middle of the design department, which is my love is innovation and quality and athletics.
So I mean, that's where I really flourished.
And I hadn't developed as a chairman.
I didn't understand public boards.
I didn't understand how to act or be.
I mean, I think people think oh, you know, I ended up with a lot of money.
You know, Chip Wilson's a businessman, but nothing really could have been further from the truth.
I'm just a passionate product guy.
So it's interesting because even though you are still the biggest shareholder, You all of a sudden had outside investors who came in and had their ideas for how this company should be run.
So I have to imagine starting in 2005, even though you're no longer CEO, there was some tension that begins.
Well, yes, I think my mistake happened when I was at West Beach and I brought in private equity.
We had boarded directors, but they had no vested interests.
They were there to help us out, and they were wonderful.

So I had this context of my mind that bringing in private equity and having a group of like really great advisors with me where we're all on the same page and moving in the same direction was going to be another wonderful experience.
Yeah.
But it wasn't.
You know, It's my own fault.
I mean, the private equity, they're there to make money for their investors.
And I had a very long-term vision for Lou Lemon, and they had quite a short-term vision for Lou Lemon.
So we ended up going public way too quickly.
Right, but when you guys went public, like in 2007, this was a hot stock.
Right, yeah.
And you actually sold a chunk of stock pretty early on, right?
Yeah, you know, again, I had advisors that were just giving me advice that was good for them and not necessarily for me.
You know, I really only wanted to sell 30% of the stock to the private equity guys, but I ended up selling 48, so I lost control of the board seats and I didn't know how to negotiate for them.

So that is important because as we go public then, you know, the advice I got was, hey Chip, you should sell more of your shares in the marketplace because the more shares that are out there, the more the institutional investors will be able to get a good chunk of it and be able to hold it for a long time.
But the reality of it is all these were techniques to have kind of an owner-founder dissipate and kind of move into the background and not have the power, so to speak, to control a board.
And that's really what I lost.
It's my own fault, but that's what I ended up with.
But this company just like went, took off, right?
I mean, through the early 2000s and to the 2000s and then it just it was on fire, right?
I mean the Lululemon was everywhere and and was is today but I mean that despite the challenges that you faced it did Explode and growth you got to admit that right?
Oh, it was unbelievable I mean, you know, okay, so things happened to me.
Big deal.

I mean, definitely I probably have a long-term vision for my family and I had a long-term vision for Lou Lemon and, you know, and those things never kind of work out perfectly but all in all I mean you'd have to admit that what occurred and what has happened is made me incredibly happy and incredibly wealthy.
So in 2011 Lou Lemon you land on the list of Canada's billionaires, which means you achieved your goal, financial security and more.
Was that like a marker for you?
Was that important for you?
Or did you think, did you not really care?
I really didn't care because again, my drives were family and my absolute passion for athletic clothing and I think my wife and I, again, we're just always so scared of losing it all.
You know, like, we could still go to the store and only buy 1 tube of toothpaste.
You know, we couldn't see ourselves buying 3, you know, to save time.
I could do it in my business, but I couldn't do it at home.

All right, so let's address the 1 elephant that everyone I say, Chip Wilson is going to be on the show, everyone says, that guy, didn't he once say, and this is the, let's just give the outlines of the story, 2013 Lula Lemon has to recall certain pants because there were concerns that they were too sheer, that they were see-through.
And in an interview you gave, offhand you said, you know, look, some of these pants just don't look good on all women's bodies.
There's Something to that effect.
And this caused an enormous uproar.
Like essentially the interpretation of it was that you were saying overweight women shouldn't wear Lululemon pants.
What happened?
What's your take on what
happened?
Well I think you have to go back and to the end of 2012, I mean I was quite frustrated with the board.
I think that the board and I didn't see eye to eye on how the company was being run.
And then there was everything I said would happen, did happen.
There was a huge quality issue.
So I went on this program on, I think it was NBC.
And Bloomberg.
Bloomberg, yes.
Bloomberg, yeah.
Thank you.
And I did know from working in the stores that there was definitely something happening to our clothing.
And I didn't know what.
Anyway, the question was really about the pilling and I said, well, what I'd
always said-
Like pilling in the, when
friction happens, the fabric pills.
Right.
Right,
OK.
You know, you've done that interview with Blakely on Spanx.
So suddenly, women were coming into the store and not wanting Lou Lemon for athletics.
They were coming in looking for it to shape their bodies.
But the sewing technique and the fabric wasn't meant for it.
So what they were doing is buying 2 to 4 sizes smaller than what their size was in order to get out of the garment what it wasn't made for.
So when you stretch anything to a limit and then you sit on a wooden bench or something like that, then pilling occurs to a greater extent.
So anyway, but I didn't know that until afterwards.
I hadn't really put two-to-two together.
I didn't realize what a big issue it was.
The words that I said were not all women.
I think something all women belong in every pair of lululemon
pants or something.
Michael Svigel You said quite frankly some women's bodies just don't, just actually don't work for lululemon pants.
Darrell Bock Yeah, yeah.
Which is a lot different than what you said
which is that a lot of people thought you said that overweight women shouldn't wear little lemon pants
yeah I mean what you said is what I think people here which is a lot different than what I said, just so we're there.
Did you get depressed?
Yeah, I'd have to say I was, because then the board took me off as chairman because they felt like I wasn't the right frontman for the company anymore and I was a liability to Lou Lemon.
I mean this is you know after 30 years of doing you know thousands of public interviews and you know I say 1 thing and then suddenly I'm a liability.
So what I

mean so how did you kind of I don't know did you did you think about that I mean I take your point that you feel like you were misunderstood and that that wasn't your intention, but whatever happened, that's what came out and that was how it was interpreted.
And did you have some time to reflect on it to think that was just I'm just that was just dumb.
Well it was a poor choice of words.
It was absolutely devastating to me.
It was devastating to my family.
I mean people would come up to my wife and go, how can you be with a man like that that would say that type of thing?
But more so it was the antithesis of everything I had built, you know, with women and for women for Lou Lemon.
It was the very opposite.
But yes, if I could take it back, I certainly would.
Is it strange?

I've asked this question of other founders, Chip, is it strange to build a company, put your blood, sweat, and tears in something that people don't pay attention to for a long time and all of a sudden everyone jumps on it when it starts to take off.
Success has a million fathers and failure is an orphan, right?
So all of a sudden, and your company, this thing you built, your idea, the name, the product, and then you're no longer in control.
Is that weird?
Yeah.

You know, my vision for Lululemon and what it could have been that is not everything that I think it can be and you know life is All about how you handle setbacks and I think Lululemon still I am them I'm the most informed cheerleader and I think it has you know, it's a great future still
You have another Do you have another business in you?
Well, what I learned is that when I left Lululemon, even though it was maybe $2 billion in sales at the time, my brain was on Lululemon being $7-8 billion.
And I had worked so hard building a company like by brick by brick that it was very...
I don't think I can go back and be a starter of a company at the age 62 anymore.
And I probably got too good a life to want to do that again.
And my absolute favourite thing I do is I've got 12 year olds, twin boys, and I'm coaching flag football.
And nothing could be more fun.
Nothing could be more fun.
Chip, you've heard the show before.
How much of your success is because of your intelligence and work and how much of it is because you were really lucky?
I think I was pure passion for athletic technical product and I would have worked 18 hours a day for the rest of my life for no money.
Now I think What happened is I got lucky because my drive and passion met a world that wanted what I wanted.
And that was the
lucky part.
That's Chip Wilson, founder of Lululemon.
Last year, the company made over $3.5 billion.
Chip hasn't been with Lululemon since 2015, but he's been staying pretty busy as the executive director of his family's holding company called Hold It All, Incorporated.
You you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you Thank you.

keywords.definition: A person who sets up and runs their own business, often taking on financial risks in the hope of earning a profit.
People who introduce new or improved methods, products, or ideas, often leading to significant changes or advancements in a particular field or industry.
People who have high moral or social standards and strive to achieve their goals through unconventional or innovative means.
A fashion trend where people wear athletic or casual clothing outside of athletic or leisure activities, often in formal or semi-formal settings.
Made from or containing cotton, a natural fiber often used in clothing and textiles.
A brand that achieves significant success or popularity, often through innovative marketing or product strategies.
Physical education, a subject taught in schools that focuses on physical activity and sports.
A person, typically a woman, who sews and repairs clothes for a living.
A type of sewing pattern, specifically a brand of pre-printed paper templates used to cut out fabric for garments.
A large-scale manufacturing process, in this context, referring to the mass production of clothing.
A long, underground pipe that transports oil from one location to another, often across long distances.

A retail strategy where a company controls multiple stages of the supply chain, from production to sales, often through direct-to-consumer sales channels, as seen in the episode where the speaker sets up a stand to sell their shorts directly to customers.
A sewing technique used to join two or more layers of fabric together, often with a decorative stitching pattern, as used by the speaker to create reversible shorts.
A type of shorts that can be worn with either side facing outwards, created by the speaker using a quilting technique and a backing fabric.
A marketing term used by the speaker to describe their loud, baggy shorts, initially targeting men who wanted an excuse to wear casual, comfortable clothing.
A brand name created by the speaker for their clothing company, inspired by their childhood experiences living on the beach in San Diego.
A situation in which a company's production costs decrease as its output increases, often due to more efficient use of resources and lower costs per unit.
A business model in which a company sells its products to other businesses, such as retailers, at a lower price than the retail price, with the intention of making a profit through volume sales.
Physical locations where a company sells its products directly to consumers, often at a higher price than wholesale prices, with the intention of making a profit through individual sales.
A type of investment in which a company or individual invests money in a private company, often with the intention of eventually taking the company public or selling it for a profit.
The estimated worth of a company's brand, including its reputation, customer loyalty, and recognition, which can be used to determine the value of a company or its products.
A state in which an individual has sufficient wealth or income to support themselves without needing to work for a living, often achieved through investments, savings, or entrepreneurship.
An event in which companies showcase their products or services to potential customers, often with the intention of generating leads, building relationships, and increasing sales.
High-end fashion designers who create custom, one-of-a-kind clothing and accessories for individual clients, often using high-quality materials and techniques.
The market for snowboarding equipment, clothing, and accessories, which includes manufacturers, retailers, and other businesses that cater to snowboarders and the sport of snowboarding.
A fabric treatment that draws sweat away from the skin and allows it to evaporate quickly, keeping the wearer dry and comfortable.
A type of seam construction that uses a specialized machine to join two pieces of fabric together, eliminating excess fabric and reducing the risk of chafing or irritation.
A type of athletic pant made from a stretchy, synthetic fabric that provides flexibility and comfort during physical activity.
A fabric treatment that prevents the growth of odor-causing bacteria, keeping clothing fresh and odor-free.
Clothing designed for specific athletic or outdoor activities, often featuring advanced materials and construction techniques to enhance performance and comfort.
A type of clothing that combines athletic and leisurewear styles, often featuring comfortable, versatile pieces that can be worn both on and off the field.
A person who studies and develops new fabrics and textile technologies, often working to create innovative materials with specific properties or performance characteristics.
A yoga-inspired athletic apparel company founded by Chip Wilson in 1998, known for its high-quality, technical athletic clothing.
Specialized characteristics of a product, such as moisture-wicking, four-way stretch, and breathability, that enhance its performance and functionality.
A man-made material used in clothing production, often mimicking the properties of natural fibers, such as cotton or wool.
A literary device in which words that start with the same sound are repeated in close proximity to each other, often used in branding and marketing.
A business model in which a company sells its products in bulk to retailers or other intermediaries, who then resell them to end consumers.
A marketing strategy that focuses on achieving a balance between revenue and expenses, often through word-of-mouth and grassroots efforts, rather than relying on advertising.
A concept in marketing and sociology that refers to the moment when a product or idea reaches a critical mass of adoption, leading to rapid growth and widespread acceptance.
A type of synthetic fabric known for its warmth, lightweight, and quick-drying properties, often used in outdoor and athletic clothing.
A type of fabric that stretches in both horizontal and vertical directions, providing flexibility and comfort in clothing.
The movement of money into or out of a business, organization, or project, typically measured over a specific period of time.
The process of increasing the size or scope of a business or operation, often to meet growing demand or expand into new markets.
The exclusive right to produce and distribute a product, often granted to a company or individual through a contract or agreement.
A business that sells goods or services directly to consumers, often through a physical storefront or online platform.
Individuals or organizations that invest money in a business or project in exchange for equity or ownership, often providing capital for growth or expansion.
The production of goods or products on a global scale, often involving international supply chains and distribution networks.
A type of investment where a firm provides capital to a company in exchange for equity, often with the goal of eventually taking the company public or selling it for a profit.
Large organizations, such as pension funds, mutual funds, and insurance companies, that invest money on behalf of their clients or beneficiaries.
A board of directors that oversees a publicly traded company, responsible for making strategic decisions and ensuring the company's financial health.
A situation where individuals or groups have a personal stake or interest in a particular outcome or decision, often due to financial or emotional investment.
A textile defect where fibers break off and form small balls or pills on the surface of a fabric, often caused by friction or wear and tear.
A method or process used to join two or more pieces of fabric together using a needle and thread, often specific to a particular type of garment or textile.
A force that opposes motion between two surfaces that are in contact, often causing wear and tear on materials.
The first public sale of a company's stock, allowing the company to raise capital and become a publicly traded entity.
Positions on a company's board of directors, often held by individuals who have a significant stake or interest in the company's success.
A strategic plan or goal that extends beyond the immediate future, often focusing on sustainable growth and development.

A person or thing whose presence or behavior is likely to cause problems or disadvantages, in this context, referring to Chip Wilson's statement that led to him being removed as chairman of Lululemon.
A person or thing that is the direct opposite of something else, in this context, referring to Chip Wilson's statement being the opposite of everything he had built for Lululemon.

A person or thing that is left without support or care, in this context, referring to the idea that failure is often left without support or recognition, while success has many people claiming responsibility.
A variation of American football that is played with flags or markers instead of tackling, in this context, referring to the sport that Chip Wilson is coaching his 12-year-old twin boys in.
A person who is responsible for overseeing the operations and strategy of an organization, in this context, referring to Chip Wilson's role in his family's holding company, Hold It All, Incorporated.
A company that owns and controls other companies or assets, in this context, referring to Hold It All, Incorporated, which is Chip Wilson's family's holding company.

highlights.highlight: So it used to be that the clothes you wore to the gym were like the absolute worst clothes you owned. You know, the ratty old t-shirt you got for free at some event, sweatpants with your high school logo, you know, the kind of short shorts Dr. J would have worn on the basketball court.

But at some point in the past 10 or 15 years, all of that changed. Because suddenly, the clothes you wore to work out were also the clothes you could wear to the grocery store or at a restaurant or even at work.
The brand he built out of his house in Vancouver is now worth more than $14 billion.
He's put his foot in his mouth on several occasions. He's embarrassed the company.

I can definitely sew. But more so, I think it was working with the butterick patterns and watching my mom lay them down on the fabric and then how she moved them and twisted them in order to save fabric.
When you can save even 5-6-7 inches of fabric, it can mean thousands of dollars.

I traded my life in for money. I mean, there was no girls, there was nothing there except for your work. So I always wonder if everyone got that opportunity, would they have made the same thing out of it I did?

I started doing what my mom did. She quilted fabric. So I would get masses of different types of patterns of fabric and then I would cut them into squares and then I would quilt them. And then in order to keep the stability of that, I put a backing on it, a black fabric, and then I realized I had reversible shorts.
I originally called them barbecue shorts because I needed to give, men needed an excuse to wear them, I knew they wanted to wear them.

I needed the volume from wholesale to get to economy of scale production to bring my prices down. And because my prices were down, my retail stores could make so much money, but I couldn't really make any money in wholesale because if I made something for $20, then I would have to sell it to Dick's Sporting Goods for $40, and then they would sell it for 80.

I knew the same thing was gonna happen in snowboarding. So when's the right time to get in? What's the right time to build? What's the right time to invest? And when to get out was always in the back of my mind.
I had paid myself probably $30, 000 to $40, 000 for 18 years. And I walked away with a million and after tax $800, 000.
I was extrapolating, but you also have to get as probably the only person in the world thinking about technical clothing outside of mountain clothing.

I had to read an article in the paper 1 day that told me that 60% of the graduates at a university were women in 1998. And I went, wow, you know, something really, really big is going to come out of this.
I went to Japan, I'd heard about these machines that were $40, 000 a piece, which was huge at the time, and I bought 4 of them. They were flat seams.

I think because when I started to do my first design meetings with these 10 groups of 10 women, and we had like 5 or 6 samples, and they touched the fabric and they put it on, it was the first time that really a synthetic fabric felt like cotton. There was nothing like it, like it was just nothing like it.

I had taken another $200, 000 loan. Wait, because the first time you ran out of money, you were running West Beach, right? Right, and I got West Beach, my old company, moved back from Salem to Vancouver, and they asked me to run it and it was like a gift out of heaven because as We were really low on money where I didn't want to advertise I wanted word of mouth to of the quality of our clothing to be the branding niche because I I really did believe in the tipping point and it had to come from people.

I actually put my first ad in as anyone that shows up gets a free outfit. And then I realized it was in Vancouver, and I was gonna get every person in the whole city would show up naked, so I couldn't really do that. So I had to put another ad in a week later saying the first 30.
I mean, I was taking triple the profit of most people.
I'd never taken any money out. My wife and I, neither of us came for money and we were always scared.
I could have done it all. But even though it was making so much money...
I had a very long-term vision for Lululemon, and they had quite a short-term vision for Lululemon. So we ended up going public way too quickly.
I really only wanted to sell 30% of the stock to the private equity guys, but I ended up selling 48, so I lost control of the board seats and I didn't know how to negotiate for them.
Some women's bodies just don't, just actually don't work for Lululemon pants.
Success has a million fathers and failure is an orphan, right? So all of a sudden, and your company, this thing you built, your idea, the name, the product, and then you're no longer in control.

I think I was pure passion for athletic technical product and I would have worked 18 hours a day for the rest of my life for no money. Now I think What happened is I got lucky because my drive and passion met a world that wanted what I wanted. And that was the lucky part.

It was a poor choice of words. It was absolutely devastating to me. It was devastating to my family. I mean people would come up to my wife and go, how can you be with a man like that that would say that type of thing?

transcript.text: As for today's show, Chip Wilson is definitely the kind of entrepreneur who is very attentive to trends.
And when he was living in Vancouver in the late 1990s, the trend he noticed was yoga.
It seemed like everyone was getting into it, particularly women.
So the story of Lululemon is a classic case of seeing an opportunity and just seizing on it.
Right place, right time.
But along the way, Chip also ran into some major problems, some of which he caused himself.
It first ran in June of 2018.
It's a super interesting story.
Hope you enjoy it.
Here it is.
People were just naked in front of the store.
Well, they showed up in their trench coats and, You know, we went out when we went to open the store.
I went out with my wife and put my arm around her.
And then we said thanks for coming.
